block.p: Iraqi Troops Not Ready, President Bush Concedes President Bush acknowledged that, 20 months after the fall of Saddam Hussein, the United States had encountered only ''mixed'' success in training Iraqi troops to secure the country, and said that it was ''unacceptable'' that some Iraqi units have fled as soon as they faced hostile fire.

F.B.I. agents witnessed abuses of prisoners by American military personnel in Iraq that included detainees being beaten, choked and having lit cigarettes placed in their ears, according to government documents released by the American Civil Liberties Union.

Iraq's interim prime minister, Ayad Allawi, said he expected the election period to include an increasing number of attacks like the car bombings and roadside executions of election officials that killed at least 70 people on Sunday. But he vowed that the Jan. 30 elections would proceed. At least 13 people were killed yesterday in an array of insurgent attacks.

A Call for Civil Disobedience The Yesha Council, Israel's main grouping of settlers, called for civil disobedience to resist the government's plans to dismantle all Israeli settlements in the Gaza Strip and four small ones in the West Bank. It is the first time the council has explicitly backed illegal activity in pursuit of its goals.

Anger Over AIDS Drug Articles A series of articles by The Associated Press critical of past trials of an AIDS drug has created a furor in Africa, causing many public health experts to worry that some countries will stop using the drug, which can prevent mothers from infecting their babies with AIDS. The National Institute for Allergy and Infectious Diseases criticized the articles.

In Face of Criticism, Bush Backs Rumsfeld President Bush gave full support to his embattled defense secretary saying that beneath Donald H. Rumsfeld's rough demeanor is a compassionate man who anguishes over the nation's losses in combat.

Tomatoes Too Ugly to Market In a season of tomato shortages, producers of a specialty tomato named UglyRipe, known for its uneven crevices and ridges, are not shipping most of their tomatoes outside Florida because of their appearance.

Woman Charged In Fetus Case The woman accused of killing a pregnant woman and cutting the baby from her womb made her first appearance in a crowded federal courtroom in Kansas City, Kan., where a judge read the charge against her: kidnapping resulting in death.

Actor's Murder Trial Opens Robert Blake, accused of murdering his wife, listened intently at the start of his trial as a prosecutor painted him as a man determined to rid himself of a woman he felt had tricked him into a loveless marriage.

More Arrests in Arson Case In the investigation into the worst residential arson in Maryland history, law enforcement officials saidthat two more people had been arrested and charged with setting fire to houses in a new subdivision.

U.S. Schools Face Competition American universities, which for half a century have attracted the world's best and brightest students, are suddenly facing intense competition as higher education undergoes rapid globalization.

Legal Aid Society Avoids Bankruptcy The Legal Aid Society, the main legal provider for New York City's poor, has reached an agreement to stave off bankruptcy after settling with its creditors, negotiating budget cuts with its lawyers and receiving an unusual $9 million donations from private law firms.

West Side Plan Criticized The Bloomberg administration's $4.1 billion plan to transform the West Side of Manhattan has run into increasing criticism from independent analysts as an expensive and risky strategy that may be impossible to pursue under current statutes.

Algae Provides Reefs with Aid Scientists have predicted that the world's coral reefs will be among the first ecosystems to suffer greatly from global warming. Some reefs, however, are proving resilient, due to the algae that live with them.
Anthony Sampson A British investigative journalist, human-rights campaigner and Nelson Mandela biographer, he was 78.

Wall Street Quietly Lobbies As President Bush prepares to unveil the details of his plan to funnel hundreds of billions of dollars of future Social Security funds into privately held investment accounts, Wall Street has begun a muted lobbying campaign, chastened by bolder forays that failed in years past.
Another Suspect Painkiller A new study has found that Aleve, a popular painkiller made by Bayer, could increase heart problems. It was the fourth pain medicine to be suspected of causing heart risks.
Even if regulators do not force Pfizer to withdraw Celebrex from the market because of risks of heart attack, its prospects are dim if doctors stop prescribing it to many people.
